trans-unit.source: Provides information about the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView"></xref> control to accessibility client applications.
Windows Forms has accessibility support built in and provides information about your application that allows it to work with accessibility client applications.
Examples of accessibility client applications are screen enlarger and reviewer utilities, voice input utilities, on-screen keyboards, alternative input devices, and keyboard enhancement utilities.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject> class inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> class to provide information about the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control to accessibility client applications.

Each class that represents a visual part of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView>—<xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell>—also contains a class that inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> to provide information about the containing class and perform actions on behalf of accessibility client applications.

There are instances when you will want to provide additional information, such as the name or description of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control, to accessibility client applications.
There are two ways of providing this additional information.

To provide limited accessibility information for existing controls, set the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleName%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDescription%2A> property values, which will be reported to accessibility client applications.

You should change the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDefaultActionDescription%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleRole%2A> property values only in rare situations, such as if you make a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> look like a list.

Occasionally, you might require more accessibility information or different accessibility actions to be included with your custom <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell>.

To customize accessibility, you can write your own class that derives from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell.DataGridViewCellAccessibleObject> classes and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method.

For example, if you are writing a custom row header cell that implements unique custom actions, such as special hit testing within your cell, you should create a class that inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.DataGridViewRowHeaderCellAccessibleObject> class and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> exposes its data structure by using <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleRole> values to define the data table hierarchy.

For more information on exposing data tables to Microsoft Active Accessibility, see "Exposing Data Tables through Microsoft Active Accessibility" in the MSDN library at http://msdn.microsoft.com/library.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject"></xref> class.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView"></xref> that owns the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject"></xref>.
Returns the child accessible object corresponding to the specified index.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.GetChild%2A> method returns an accessible object for the row of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell> objects when <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.ColumnHeadersVisible%2A> is `true` and `index` is 0.

If <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.ColumnHeadersVisible%2A> is `false` and `index` is 0, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.GetChild%2A> returns an accessible object for the first <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow>.
The zero-based index of the child accessible object.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> that represents the child accessible object corresponding to the specified index.
Returns the number of child objects belonging to an accessible object.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.GetChildCount%2A> method returns the number of visible rows in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView>, plus 1 for the column header row if it is visible and 1 for each visible scroll bar.
If there are no columns in the control, this method always returns 0.
The number of child objects belonging to the accessible object.
Returns the accessible object of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell"></xref> that has the keyboard focus.

An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> that specifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell"></xref> that has the current focus, or `null` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView"></xref> does not have focus.
Returns an <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> that represents the selected cells in the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView"></xref> control.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> that represents the currently selected cells, or `null` if no cells are selected or if the object itself does not have focus.
Retrieves the child object at the specified screen coordinates.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.HitTest%2A> method returns an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> that represents part of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView>.
If the object itself is at the specified location, this method returns the calling object.
The following table describes what the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> represents.
Area clicked
Object represented by accessible object
Column header cell
Row header cell
Cell
Scroll bar
The horizontal screen coordinate.
The vertical screen coordinate.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> that represents an object at the given screen coordinates, or `null` if no object is at the specified location.
Gets or sets the accessible object name.
The accessible object name.
Navigates to another accessible object.

Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.FirstChild> value to get the first child accessible object of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject>, and use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.LastChild> to get the last child.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject.Navigate%2A> method will return `null` for all other values of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation> enumeration.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation"></xref> values.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> that represents the object positioned at the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation"></xref> value.
Gets the role of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleRole.Table"></xref> value.
